conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the position and size of the object and the light source.
When the light source is higher, shadows tend to be longer and more spread out.
When the light source moves downward, shadows become shorter and more concentrated.

premise: When the light source moves downward, shadows become shorter and more concentrated.
conclusion: As the light source moves downward, the shadows will shift closer to their respective objects.
When the light source is higher, shadows are larger because the light rays have to travel a longer distance to reach the ground, spreading out more.
When the light source moves downward, the light rays have a shorter distance to travel, causing the shadows to become smaller and more focused.

premise: When the light source moves downward, the light rays have a shorter distance to travel, causing the shadows to become smaller and more focused.
conclusion: Shadow A (Ice Cream) moves closer to the ice cream and becomes smaller as the light source comes down.
